title: 108_hr3457
content: The Act titled "Improving Government Accountability Act of 2003" aims to enhance the independence of Inspectors General. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to allow for the removal of an Inspector General from office for reasons such as permanent disability, inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance, or conviction of a felony or conduct involving moral turpitude. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to establish a seven-year term of office for each Inspector General, with provisions for filling vacancies before the term expires. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to allow Inspectors General to directly submit budget requests to Congress, in addition to the head of the establishment involved. Each budget submitted by the President must include a separate statement for the amount requested by each Inspector General, along with a comparison of their request and the funds requested by the establishment head. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to establish the Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency. The Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency is established as an independent entity within the executive branch to increase professionalism and effectiveness of personnel in the offices of the Inspectors General. Membership includes all Inspectors General established in the Inspector General Act of 1978 and subsequent amendments, the Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and the Associate Deputy Director. The Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency includes key members such as the Associate Deputy Director of the FBI, the Director of the Office of Government Ethics, the Special Counsel of the Office of Special Counsel, and others. The chairman is chosen from among the Inspectors General and serves for a three-year term. The Council meets at least semiannually and is responsible for identifying and reviewing functions and duties. The Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency is tasked with identifying weaknesses in federal programs to fraud, waste, and abuse. They develop coordinated plans for government-wide activities to address these issues and promote efficiency. The Council also plays a role in developing policies for a well-trained workforce. The Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency establishes a corps of well-trained staff members who adhere to professional standards. The Council's creation and operation do not interfere with existing agency authority. The Chair may appoint a Vice Chair and establish the agenda for Council activities. The Chair of the Council reports to the President on activities, advises on considerations, provides summary reports to agency heads, and establishes necessary committees. Executive Order 12805 is revoked, and amendments are made to the Inspector General Act of 1978. The U.S.C. App. is amended to replace references to "section 11(2)" with "section 12(2)" in various sections. Additionally, $750,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009 to carry out this section. SEC. 5. PERSONNEL FLEXIBILITIES. Amends the Inspector General Act of 1978 to include a personnel management system. The Office of Personnel Management maintains a personnel management system for officers and employees of various Offices of Inspector General. The system includes principles of title 5, prohibits certain personnel practices and political activities, and ensures proper appointments. The personnel management system for Officers and Employees of various Offices of Inspector General ensures appointments based on merit, without regard to certain provisions of title 5. The system also allows the Inspector General to set basic pay in line with section 5301 of title 5. The Office of Personnel Management publishes a basic pay schedule, with the highest rate not exceeding GS-15, except as provided under section 5349(a) of title 5. The personnel management system for Officers and Employees of various Offices of Inspector General includes adjustments to basic pay rates in line with the General Schedule, entitlement to grade and basic pay retention, performance appraisals, reduction in grade or removal for unacceptable performance, and other personnel actions consistent with chapter 75 of title 5. The personnel management system includes procedures for processing complaints and grievances, ensuring personnel actions are taken without discrimination, and implementing a minority recruitment program. The Office of Personnel Management prescribes regulations for separation of officers or employees during a reduction in force, giving priority to tenure of employment, military preference, and veterans' preference. The regulations for separation of officers or employees during a reduction in force prioritize factors such as performance ratings, length of service, and other objective factors determined by the relevant Inspector General. Regulations for removal from the Senior Executive Service in a reduction in force must be consistent with section 3595(a) of title 5. An officer or employee may not be released due to a reduction in force unless specified exceptions apply. An officer or employee facing release in a reduction in force must receive written notice at least 60 days in advance, detailing the personnel action, effective date, procedures for selection, ranking compared to others, and available appeal rights. The Inspector General can shorten this notice period in certain circumstances. The regulations for reduction in force require a notice period of at least 30 days, with provisions for voluntary separation to retain similar positions. This section does not supersede certain provisions related to personnel management. In the application of title 5, United States Code, each Office of Inspector General is considered a separate agency. References to agency heads in relation to an Office of Inspector General are considered to refer to the Inspector General. Voluntary separation provisions apply to Offices of Inspector General as separate agencies. In the application of title 5, United States Code, each Office of Inspector General is considered a separate agency. References to agency heads in relation to an Office of Inspector General are considered to refer to the Inspector General who is the head of such Office. Voluntary separation provisions apply to Offices of Inspector General as separate agencies. Section 5(b) of the Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to require semiannual reports from each Inspector General to be submitted to Congress by January 31 and July 31 of each year. The head of the establishment involved may also submit a report to Congress within 30 days of receiving the Inspector General's report.
